The adventure continues! An incredible mystical forest full of wondrous creatures is cared for by a powerful mage. He offers you a quest involving a runaway dragon and a city in the sky. Now the excitement begins!

199733.name: Squeeerrels
199733.description:
Leader, Speedy and Strongman make a great team! Develop a strategy to stock up on nuts by playing to your team strength!

Squeeerrels is a simple game about squirrels gathering nuts. The gameplay consist of three stages.

Stage one - Exploring
The cards are shuffled and organised in 4 or 5 piles (depending on the number of players). Now each player may view the cards of one forest and the last player may view two forests.

Stage two - To the forest
Players in turn order assign all of their squirrels one at a time.

Stage three - Collecting the nuts
All forest cards are revealed. At first every hedgehog takes one nut. Now the squirrels take what's left unless the marten prevents them. The squirrels may also use their special abilities. Speedy may take a nut before hedgehog takes one. Strongman may take two nuts instead of one. Leader may change forests with one its teammates.

After 3 or 4 rounds (depending on number of players) the game ends. The person who has the highest number of nuts is the winner and Squeeerrel The Strategist!

199734.name: How to Write Adventure Modules that Don't Suck
199734.description:
From the Introduction:

For nearly a decade, Goodman Games has been publishing adventure modules generally considered to be among the best in the industry. With more than 100 adventures in print and the single longest-running adventure module brand on the market, Goodman Games has established a track record for writing adventures that don’t suck.

At Gen Con 2007 we ran a seminar called “How To Write Adventure Modules That Don’t Suck,” which was packed to standing room only. This has quickly become one of our most popular Gen Con events. This year, we’ve expanded our offerings to include this book of essays. Compiled from experienced adventure writers with multiple published adventure credits, these essays should provide tips to improve your adventure writing skills. We hope you benefit from improved home games and perhaps drive some quality submissions in our direction.

Regardless of the advice offered here or elsewhere, remember that the primary definition of an adventure that doesn’t suck is one that your players enjoy. If your gaming group walks away happy and has stories to tell for years to come, it was a great adventure. I hope this booklet provides you with some more of those adventures.

199735.name: The Black Hack Gamemaster's Screen
199735.description:
From the publisher:

This is a mini GM screen for the Black Hack, a super-streamlined roleplaying game that uses the Original 1970s Fantasy Roleplaying Game as a base. It could well be the most straightforward modern OSR-compatible clone available. If speed of play and character creation, compatibility, and simple - yet elegant rules are what you yearn for. Look no further!

199736.name: The Goblin Commander
199736.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is the third Extension Quest for the Labyrinth Adventures Gaming System...
A dwindling race of toad people within the realm of Sulfus have a serious goblin problem and you’re stuck in this horrible backwater with them. You and your party decide to engage in a carefully planned attack upon the goblin hordes and their fearsome commander! But, have you bitten off more than you can chew?...

199737.name: A Dead Awakening
199737.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is the forth Expansion Quest Module for the Labyrinth Adventures Gaming System...

Your quest for treasure might finally pay off big as you hear of a vast strike of silver in the Korgothian Hills. You are well on your way into the region when you find out that the forest and beyond may not only be full of riches, it may also be haunted. Will you prosper, or will you join the dead?

boardgamecompilation.199743: Cool Mini Or Not Promo Pack 2016

199738.description: This is a promotional card given away at Cool Mini Or Not's 2016 CMON Expo. This card is an ultrared weapon that takes two combat actions to use.
199738.name: Zombicide: M134 Gatling Promo Card

boardgamecompilation.199743: Cool Mini Or Not Promo Pack 2016

199739.description: This is a promotional card given away at Cool Mini Or Not's 2016 CMON Expo. This card is a spell that has a chance to freeze zombies in place for a turn.
199739.name: Zombicide: Black Plague – Ice Blast Promo Card

boardgamecompilation.199743: Cool Mini Or Not Promo Pack 2016

199740.description: A promotional item that was given away at Cool Mini Or Not's 2016 CMON Expo, this card is an upgraded "Plasma Arc" Shotgun, which can cancel an enemy's reveal ability, but also has the potential to deal additional damage when the equipped troop is killed.
199740.name: XenoShyft: Oathkeeper Promo Card

boardgamecompilation.199743: Cool Mini Or Not Promo Pack 2016

199741.description: This is a promotional set of cards given away at Cool Mini Or Not's 2016 CMON Expo. These four cards are each a slingshot weapon that is stronger if you don't use your movement.
199741.name: Arcadia Quest: Steady Slingshot Promo Pack

boardgamecompilation.199743: Cool Mini Or Not Promo Pack 2016

199742.description: This is a promotional set of cards given away at Cool Mini Or Not's 2016 CMON Expo. These four cards offer different abilities for your characters.
199742.name: B-Sieged: Sons of the Abyss – Promo Pack 2016

199743.name: Cool Mini Or Not Promo Pack 2016

boardgamecompilation.199741: Arcadia Quest: Steady Slingshot Promo Pack

199743.description: This is a promotional set of cards given away at Cool Mini Or Not's 2016 CMON Expo. There are 11 cards split amongst the following 5 games: Zombicide, Zombicide: Black Plague, Xenoshyft, Arcadia Quest, and B-Sieged.

199745.name: Moose Caboose
199745.description:
Four trains full of happy animals are chugging off on an adventure. The player who collects the most animal cards, by matching colors, wins the game!

Play starts by removing the 4 Engine cards and then dealing out 4 Train cards face down to each player. The remaining cards form a draw pile. One at a time, players match a colored train card from their hand to the same colored engine or train card on the table. Then they replenish their hand to 4 cards. If a player gets a Moose Caboose card, they can match that to the same colored train card in play. After it is played, the player scoops up all the train cards from that engine. The game ends when there are no more cards left or when no one can make a play. Whoever has collected the most train cards wins.

199746.name: Spark Class Scout
199746.description:
From publisher blurb:

The space craft introduced in this installment of the Starships series is a small and affordable scout for a crew of up to four.

The PDF contains the background of the ship, statistics for it and an example crew. In addition the document contains simple deckplans (Without scale or grid!) of the ship and images showing the ship from various directions.

199747.name: Australian Realms (Issue 10 - Mar/Apr 1993)
199747.description:
Australian Realms
Issue 10
March - April 1993


Battletech
Blood Bowl
Lizards
Vampire
AD&D
UNAE

199748.name: The Lost Temple of Forgotten Evil: Side Quests - River Crossing
199748.description:
From publisher blurb:

Side Encounter: Caravan Crossing the River

This is a prequel/preview encounter, useful if the party needs a little more XP before starting The Lost Temple of Forgotten Evil. It also provides some intrigue. While written as a preview to a specific product, this encounter can be easily adapted to any campaign world.

The small town of Boldon, and its surrounding villages are afraid. Dozens of people are missing, some speculate lost to some nefarious purpose. A broken drunkard tells fantastic tales of an evil temple and the horrible things within. The rare few who know the legends and history of the region are beginning to think the dark times have returned; not seen since the fall of the first age of man. People are beginning to feel the icy fingers of fear closing in. The party becomes aware of these events and is inspired to investigate. This leads them to a broken man who tells them a story of a lost temple. Has it been rediscovered by men seduced by its forgotten evil? The drunkard’s tale leads to others who might help the party discover more before they face The Lost Temple of Forgotten Evil.

199749.name: Roleplaying Tips (Issue 699)
199749.description:
Roleplaying Tips
Issue 699
May 2016


Brief Word From Johnn
5 PC Home Base Tips
20 Random Home Bases and the Qualities that Make Them Special
20 Home Base Threats
20 Home Base Secrets

199750.name: The Starrunner Kit: A Sci-Fi Space Toolkit
199750.description:
From publisher blurb:

It’s time to set a course through the stars! The Starrunner Kit is here to provide new classes, races, weapons, Mechs, and a huge tool kit for instant generation for your White Star (or other OSR flavored sci-fi games).

If you want to be a Scoundrel, Assassin, Hover Bike Rider, or even an Alien Psychic Weapon or Plant-like Lifeform, you’ll find it in Starrunner Kit. Looking for Mech rules or a quick way to generate a planet, mission, space station, or even generate stuff for a sci-fi hexcrawl? It’s all here. All you need is some dice and some players ready to set a course for adventure!

The galaxy is your backyard; It’s time to adventure...

199751.name: The Black Hack: Cyber-Hacked!
199751.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Black Hack: Cyber-Hacked! takes the awesome OSR rules created by David Black for The Black Hack and uses them to create a OSR-style cyberpunk system. Simple rules for hacking, cyberware, car chases, drugs, and guns are included.

Which class will you choose to be when running in the shadows and doing jobs for the local Fixer? Will you be The Street Meat, The Martial Artist, The Street Rat, The Mechanic, The Face, or The Psychic? Do you have what it takes to survive a run through a corporate Acrology to obtain secret plans? Let's roll some dice and find out!

199754.name: Tvilling Bergen
199754.description:
From the introduction:

Detta äventyr är gjort för dig som är spelledare i Drakar & Demoner. Om du är en spelare bör du, för ditt eget nöjes skull, sluta läsa omedelbart. Du som är spelledare bör däremot noga läsa igenom hela äventyret, helst flera gånger, så att du slipper sitta och bläddra och leta under spelets gång. Det finns inget som är så tråkigt för spelarna som en SL som ideligen avbryter sig för att sitta tyst och läsa för sig själv.

Du behöver inte kunna allting utantill, men läs äventyret så noggrant att du verkligen förstår vad som sägs och var det sägs.

Äventyret startar i den lilla byn Vindpina, en blåsig håla belägen c:a 5 dags-marscher från Sarnath (Gamla Sarnath) och tre dagsmarscher från Tvillingbergen.

199755.name: Adventure Chronicle (Issue #1 - Spring 2016)
199755.description:
From publisher blurb:

Contents for issue #1:

Publisher's Corner by Jonathan G. Nelson

Adventure (5E): A Shoggoth Among the Sheep by Wolfgang Baur

Review: Pixies on Parade by Endzeitgeist

Review: Shattered Heart #1 – The Ties that Bind by Endzeitgeist

Review: Ultimate Charisma by Endzeitgeist

Review: Return to Crypt of the Sun Lord by Endzeitgeist

Musings of a Mermaid: Interview with Jen Page by Jonathan G. Nelson

S.A.G.E. Advice for Enjoying your Game by Jen Page

Comic: Tales from the Tabletop by Jacob Blackmon

Rites of Spring by Will Myers

Birth of a Freelancer by Michael Allen

Rules for Falling in Love by Stephen Yeardley

The Menagerie: Reliquum by Michael Smith

The Menagerie: Froojarr Midgekind by Stephen Yeardley

The Arcanarium: Copper Disc of Spring Feeding by Stephen Yeardley

The Arcanarium: Halter of Training by Stephen Yeardley

The Arcanarium: Herbalist's Terrarium by Justin Andrew Mason

Mini-Adventure (PF): The Spirit Bottle by Stephen Yeardley

Mini-Adventure (PF): Fitcher's by Stephen Yeardley

The Gauntlet: Map Trap by Rory Toma

The Gauntlet: Structurally Unsound Door Trap by Rory Toma

The Gauntlet: Navigation Trap by Rory Toma

The Gauntlet: Thin Ice Trap by Rory Toma

The Gauntlet: Navigation Trap by Rory Toma

199756.name: Grackle's Vale and the Boarman of Reeker's Keep
199756.description:
From the Introduction:

The otherwise peaceful village of Grackle’s Vale has been terrorized of late by a creature that has taken up lair in the nearby ruins of Reeker’s Keep. It is a Boarman, a foul lycanthrope said to haunt dark forests and murky mires, feared for its savagery and accursed tusks. At least a dozen people have gone missing after attempting to track the beast, the most recent being a Ranger of some renown. A reward of 1000 gold pieces has been offered to anyone willing to help free the community from the Boarman’s bloodlust.

This booklet is part of a series of supplements detailing the villages around the Bay of Spirits. The bay is located on the western edge of the Eastern Sea. Dotted with hamlets, villages and small towns, it is an excellent place for adventure and exploration.

This is a region of sheer cliffs, forested mountains, dark gullies, and bottomless ravines. Settlements along the coast walk a thin line between land and sea, with farmers, fishermen, traders, and sellswords plying their trade alongside merchants, nobles, rogues, and adventurers. Each community contains colorful characters, detailed settings, and helpful tidbits to enhance any medieval fantasy game setting. Grackle’s Vale is the first of such communities.

199757.name: Ten Cent Maps
199757.description:
From the Introduction:

What follows is an assortment of fantasy maps and illustrations that can easily be dropped into any medieval campaign setting.

Ranging from full color villages to black and white town illustrations, each is hand drawn and original. If you would like your world to have an old-school gaming feel then this supplement should fit right in. Several maps have a description included that could serve as inspiration for a setting or be used for an impromptu night of gameplay. Each map can be used separately, as a series, or as a part of a complete setting. They are yours to populate and fill out as you see fit. Enjoy!

199758.name: d66 Compendium 2
199758.description:
'From the Introduction:

As I mentioned in the introduction to the d66 Compendium, the idea for our d66 list series originally came from the Ultimate Toolbox from AEG, which I helped write. However, space limitations required that I cut some details. The first list of names I wrote for a roleplaying game came years before then. While running a Star Wars game (WEG d6, 2nd Edition), I had to come up with a planet name in a hurry, and I named it “Yaffa” after the blocks, because it was on a commercial the group saw before playing the game. Afterwards, one of the players suggested I write a list of names of people and planets so I would not have to think of one in the moment. That is a trick
I have used in every game I have run since. So, the first D66 lists I published were lists that I created for my own use.

No matter what edition of Traveller you play, this book is ideal for it. Additionally, this book can help you beyond the Traveller Roleplaying Game, in any science fiction roleplaying game. Anytime you need ship names, details on where a criminal is hiding, strange names for aliens that are easy to pronounce,
or reasons for a planet-wide quarantine, this book will be right there to help you. Be sure to tell not only your friends that play Traveller, but also any fans of sci-fi roleplaying games you know, about the D66 Compendium 2 and the d66 Compendium.

199759.name: Fantasy Campaign Builder
199759.description:
From the Front Cover:
With this guide you can quickly roll... Town names, sizes, government types, Inn and Tavern names, NPC names, Campaign and Villain Ideas and much MORE!

No DM should be with out this!

199760.name: Beyond Flesh and Blood
199760.description:
Ethan is one of Earth’s last few good men in the United Global Remnant forces (UGR) following a series of global disasters. After failing his pilot test and years in orbit on survivor ark Astralis, he finally returns to Earth. Mechs and drones rule what's left. The only way back is through the mind-powered VR on board, controlling these huge, clearance level mechs which hover in pods above the planet.

But with the UGR, there are truths, and there are lies.

Source: The Game Website.

199761.name: Old School Adventures Accessory GM1: Game Master's Screen
199761.description:
From the Publisher's Marketing Information:

This is the most comprehensive GM screen ever created for BX editions of the original RPG and comparable retro-clones. The inside and outside faces of each screen will be printed on 15 pt. cover stock, and glued together to create 30 pt. thickness!!!

The exterior of this 6-panel (12-page) screen features artwork by the legendary artist Arthur Rackham, and content panels include all the pertinent information any Classic (BX/LL) GM needs to run their game, including:

Experience point & spell level progressions for each character class
Class-based combat & saving throw tables
Class abilities & attribute adjustments
Tables for Clerical turning and Thieves' abilities
Variable damage by weapon; missile fire ranges; AC by armor type
Step-by-step outlines for both turn sequence & combat sequence
A simplified Treasure Types table
Comprehensive cost lists for weapons, equipment, and animals
Complete movement information (including dungeon, wilderness, airborne, and encumbered movement)
Henchmen/hirelings, mercenaries & specialists (recruitment, requirements, salaries, and abilities)

199762.name: Grand Kingdom
199762.description:
Players engage in turn-based battles where they command groups of mercenaries who are able to attack using swords and magic attacks, depending on the specific combat class each unit belongs to. Battles involve arranging the positions of units into formations and executing action techniques.

Source: Wikipedia, "[en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Kingdom Grand Kingdom]", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

199763.name: Silent Night
199763.description:
From the publisher blurb:

Silent Night is an EPOCH Christmas Special; a one-shot survival horror scenario with all proceeds being donated to children in need through the United NaEPOCH Christmas Specialtions Children's Fund (UNICEF).

I'm dreaming of a white Christmas...

"...shutting down as blizzard conditions come out of nowhere..."

with every Christmas card I write

"...there's a lot of passengers facing Christmas in an airport terminal Chuck..."

May your days be merry and bright

"...please if anyone can hear us, help, please, there's something out there... Please help us! It's coming!"

And may all your Christmases be white

199764.name: Supreme Gangster
199764.description:
Supreme Gangster is a fast paced competitive game for 2-4 players, where each player assumes the role as leader of an organized crime gang in a small American town during 1920's prohibition. You choose from 16 different Capos to manage a crew of street thugs to grow your criminal empire. All players play against one another competing for territory and control of the criminal market. You will operate criminal establishments all while evading police and gunning your rivals into extinction. You could even bribe police, judges, and city councilmen to work for you and leverage their positions of power to hinder your enemies!

Object of the game is to be the first gang to satisfy one of four different winning conditions before prohibition is repealed. Winning conditions are as follows:

1. Control the largest criminal empire
2. Bankrupt all rival gangs
3. Kill three rival Capos
4. Bribe all City Officials

A game round will consist of all players drawing an Event card which will consist of additional weapons or abilities. Next, each player starting with the first player takes a turn moving their thugs and Capos to try to control as many illegal establishments as possible. The more establishments you control the more money and more powerful your empire becomes. If any rival gangsters work their way into your territory you could remove them by force. This will consist of either a fight or a gun attack. Both are resolved easily by rolling dice and adding the total. At the end of each turn, the player will total up their income and make any purchases.

After each player has taken their turn, then the RAID phase will begin. During the RAID phase, the first player will draw a RAID card. This could range from establishments being raided or having to accomplish a task to prevent something negative. When the RAID phase is complete, then the Prohibition Chart moves down one level closer to repeal. The player to the left becomes the new first player and the next round begins.

So get dressed in your best suit, put on a pot of spaghetti sauce, and don’t forget your machine gun. Will you be the next Supreme Gangster?

199765.name: Heavy Gods!
199765.description:
From the Introduction:

It's the Stellar Year 4,576.

The future’s a dirty, all-analogue place. Technology got more advanced, but the culture and politics of this f*&^edup future still stinks like 1976. The galaxy's equal parts grunge and glam, polyester and leather. It’s a place where billowing Afros never went out of style, where the heroes spark up joints the size of a baby's forearm and blast off for the Frontier. It's a galaxy of stoner nomads cruising the galactic backwaters at FTL speed, banging cute alien spacers with only a cheap-ass Dr. Youp’s Condom to protect them. It's a place where the smuggler always shoots first, and the Cosmic Televangelists of the Imperial Church of the Galaxy are always tryin' to get their cut.

It's a Heavy Future, where futurism takes a back seat to pulpy, retro-futuristic, blasphemous kick-ass adventuring. That's all you really need to know. We'll make up the rest as we go along.

Faiths of the Heavy Future

We’ve said before that Heavy Future's all about blasphemous, kick-ass adventuring.

So what's that mean?

What kind of gods and things do the people of the year 4,576 worship anyway? What’s up with the Imperial Church of the Galaxy? Who do the Cosmic Satanists pray to?

Find out in Heavy Gods! This short sourcebook details all the major religions popular in the Heavy Future, as well as a couple new archetypes for the Cleric class suitable to the world, and a few new clerical domains and bunch of new subdomains.

199766.name: Listography: The Game
199766.description: Listography invites players to create and share lists based on fun and thought-provoking topics, from geography and pop culture to toothpaste and constellations! With the goal of being the first around the game board, players score points according to the number of similar or unique answers.

199767.name: Screamer 2
199767.description:
User Summary

Screamer 2 is a rally car racing game, featuring hardware accelerated 3D graphics and networked multiplayer.

199768.name: 9DKP
199768.description:
An ancient legend speaks of an evil known as Babusa, a 9-tailed demon Kat, that could raise the dead and had a penchant for inflicting unending plight on mankind. Eventually defeated by having his 9 tails cut off, Babusa was locked away for what many hoped would be an eternity. His nine tails, still oozing magical power, were given to a select few. The tails Imbued the owners with the ability to transform into magical warrior kats just in case Babusa were to ever rise again. That day has come, and with it so has total chaos! Choose your side and prepare to fight in 9DKP (9 Deadly Kat Points!).

9DKP is a Trading Card Game (TCG), that takes place in the 9DKP universe created by Erick Scarecrow. The objective with the 9DKP TCG was to bring the fun and wacky flavor of the 9DKP universe to table top with a TCG that is light and easy to learn.

TCGs can often be intimidating for payers to get invested in due to their complexity of rules, card sets, and time commitment, from playing to deck building. 9DKP is lighter than most TCGs. 9DKP is a great starting point for people who are developing an interest in TCGs, families with younger gamers, or for casual gamers looking for something a bit simpler than the other TCGs on the market.

Gameplay in 9DKP is very simple, consisting of 2 phases.

Phase 1 – Draw: draw 1 new card into your hand.

Phase 2 – Active: During the active phase you do the follow:

Wake up any character cards that are in Katnap.
Play 1 character card into your RANGE (with a max of 4 cards in your RANGE at one time). Generate or spend the corresponding DKP value of the card. That card enters in Katnap and cannot attack or defend during this turn unless otherwise stated.
Play any number of skratch cards you wish as long as you can afford the associated DKP cost.
Play passes to your opponent.

Unlike other TCGs, 9DKP’s 2 phases keep the turn lengths short and simple. Skratch cards, that work like spells or magical effects in other TCGS, can only be played on your turn and currently there are no interrupt or cancel cards.

199769.name: Redcoats
199769.description:
From the inlay:

Redcoats is an all graphic wargame, for either 1 or 2 players, set during the American war of independence.

The programme allows for full use of cavalry, infantry and artillery forces, and contains 5 different battle scenarios as well as the facility to modify or create your own scenarios.

User Summary

The original was the BBC/Electron version by Mike Williams, with conversions to the Amstrad by Choice and to the Spectrum by Andy Pugh.

199770.description:
This set of game aids for Food Chain Magnate contains two elements:


A card accordion that fits the box bottom, with icons of each card shown on the accordion to help with set-up.



Five sturdy dry erase boards of all the milestones, German on one side, English on the other.


This set both shrinks the required table space to play the game significantly, while also being a much handier way to both reference and track reached and expired milestones!
199770.name: Food Chain Magnate: Milestone Boards & Card Accordion

199771.name: Screamer Rally
199771.description:
User Summary

Screamer Rally is a racing game, featuring hardware accelerated 3D graphics and both split screen and networked multiplayer. It also features tracks set in China, Canada, Italy, Arizona, Sweden and England.

199773.name: Cats & Caverns
199773.description:
Cats & Caverns is a cooperative game for 2-6 players where you play the role of a house cat–ahem–feline hero.

You and your team are working to rid the realm–your home–of a Big Cheese, along with his villainous rats, that has taken up residence in a nearby network of caverns under the house.

Traps have been laid and henchmen lie in wait for you. Defeat them for treasure–things around the house, really–and continue to until you find and defeat the Big Cheese!

While adventuring in the caverns:

A lineup is created based on the number of players
Villains and traps are ordered by speed.
Heroes each roll a D20, adding their speed bonuses, and join the battle lineup in order. Heroes can, at the start of battle, choose to be later in the lineup for strategic purposes.
Once ordered, heroes will take their turns, attacking or disarming traps as desired.
When each cavern is cleared, they will then roll on potential loot based on the Cavern Card and the battle mode (cat or beast) chosen.

199774.name: Under Construction
199774.description:
Under Construction is a 2-6 player worker placement game that puts players in the role of general contractor.

You need to win contracts (lowest hidden bid wins), collect the necessary resources, and then build them in order to get cash and increase your reputation.

With a modest amount of bluffing, resource management, worker placement and Development Cards—that can help you or harm others—there’s a little something for everyone.

199775.name: Dr. Spacezoo
199775.description:
UNRELEASED GAME – AVAILABLE




This game is still either in Early-Alpha or Beta (or any status in between) but IS already available for sale / early access, so CAN BE PLAYED.




Rescue exotic space animals from a corrupt AI in Dr. Spacezoo, a chaotic twin-stick precision shoot-em-up.

Source: The Game Website.

199776.name: Don't Drink The Kool Aid
199776.description:
Don’t Drink the Kool Aid is a 15-card card game for 4-7 players where, oddly enough, you find yourself at a cult gathering.


You may be the Detective trying to find the Cult Leader.
You may be the Cult Leader trying to get as many people to drink the Kool Aid as possible.
You may be a Cultist who wants to drink the Kool Aid and make sure that everyone else does too.
Or you may be a non-believer who’s here because you had nothing better to do... and know better than to drink the Kool Aid.


This quick game is played in up to 5 rounds where points are earned for achieving your role’s desires.

On your turn you may either:

Look at 2 Drink Cards
Swap 2 Drink Cards
Learn 1 player's role (non-believer or cultist)
Attempt to arrest the Cult Leader (Detective only)
Pass




Turns continue until either the detective attempts to arrest someone or everyone has had 5 turns.

Now drink up and count the points!

199777.name: Midnight Raid!
199777.description:
From the introduction:

You are all horse addicts locked inside a drug dealer’s den. He suspects that one of you is an Undercover Agent. He’s right! Until you Burn the Agent, he won’t let you out or give you more horse. If things get too rowdy, he’ll just kill all of you. If you don’t find the agent before midnight, the cops will raid the den and the agent wins. The game starts at noon...

199778.name: A Rodent Problem
199778.description:
From the introduction:

Ah, yes. The town has a problem with rats that are larger than usual coming out of the sewers, attacking people, and causing damage to shops. Any brave soul who is willing to go into the sewers to take the rats out will be grouped together with other honest adventurers and given a key to the iron grates that bar entry to the city sewers.

This adventure is designed to be run with just the basic rules that can be downloaded from the official D&D website.

A 1 to 2-hour adventure for 1st level characters

199779.name: Old Empires Spells
199779.description:
From the introduction:

Sixteen spells adapted from the old Forgotten Realms accessory, FR10 Old Empires. Some of these spells introduce some new concepts or powers that may not fit into all play styles. Make sure you check them first before allowing them.

User summary:

Includes four Bard spells, three Cleric spells, two Druid spells, one Paladin spell, seven sorcerer spells, two warlock spells, and eight wizard spells.

199780.description:
In Looterz, players are racing to collect the most loot possible by recruiting a team of Looterz. Your loot is never safe though as many Looterz have the ability to steal Loot from other players.

A player's turn involves four phases: Recruitment, Looter Activation, Recruitment, then Sacrifice. Each recruitment phase allows the player to draw a card from the deck or put a Looter from their hand into play. Players are then allowed to choose to activate their Looterz in any order. Finally, if players have more than three Looterz in play, they must discard down to three.

Looting is resolved by rolling dice. The number of hearts on a Looter indicates the number of dice a player may roll during the Loot resolution.
199780.name: Looterz

199781.name: Orinpikku nekkyō yūgiban
199781.description:
オリンピック熱狂遊戯盤 [= Olympic frenzy board game]
Board game issued August 1932 as a supplement to volume 19, no. 8 of the monthly magazine "Shonen Club".
The game was produced at the time of the 1932 Los Angeles Olympics. Four players represent the USA, France, Japan and the UK. Each has 4 starting counters (athletes), who must move to the centre of the circular board (bypassing the unplayable spaces representing Finnish, Norwegian, German and Canadian competitors), collect a 'laurel wreath' and return to the goal behind the player's 4 starting spots.
Paper-scissors-rock is used to determine which player is able to move one of his athletes to an adjacent space. If a player's athlete lands on another player's, the two play paper-scissors-rock again: the winner can move to an adjacent space, the loser's is eliminated.
The reverse side of the board features name and photographs of all the Japanese athletes who competed at the 1932 Los Angeles Olympics.

199782.name: The Imperial Seagull (Issue 1 - Feb 2016)
199782.description:
From the publisher's blurb:

Grab a copy of the “Imperial Seagull” and start living in Waterdeep! In each issue you'll read the latest Waterdhavian news and rumors and find a solid piece of crunch for your 5th edition Dungeons & DragonsTM game.

199783.name: The Imperial Seagull (Issue 2 - Feb 2016)
199783.description:
From the publisher's blurb:

Grab a copy of the “Imperial Seagull” and start living in Waterdeep! In each issue you'll read the latest Waterdhavian news and rumors and find a solid piece of crunch for your 5th edition Dungeons & DragonsTM game.

199784.name: The Imperial Seagull (Issue 3 - May 2016)
199784.description:
From the publisher's blurb:

Grab a copy of the Imperial Seagull and start living in Waterdeep! In each issue you'll read the latest Waterdhavian news and rumors and find a solid piece of crunch for your 5th edition Dungeons & DragonsTM game.

199785.name: The Imperial Seagull (Issue 4 - May 2016)
199785.description:
From the publisher's blurb:

Grab a copy of the Imperial Seagull and start living in Waterdeep! In each issue you'll read the latest Waterdhavian news and rumors and find a solid piece of crunch for your 5th edition Dungeons & DragonsTM game.

199787.description:
A version of 'snakes and ladders' themed around the federation of the Australian colonies. The numbered board spaces from 1841 to 1901 represent years. Players roll the die and move towards 1901, moving up ladders and down snakes if they land on these. In addition, some spaces require a player to answer a trivia card on some topic of Australian constitutional history. A correct or wrong answer moves the player forward or back 2 spaces respectively .
Comes with folding board with rules printed on it, and deck of 34 cards. The die and player tokens required for play do not seem to have been included.
Produced by the Departments of the Senate and of the House of Representatives, of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia.
199787.name: The Federation Game

199789.name: Screamer 4x4
199789.description:
User Summary

Screamer 4x4 is an off-road driving game with an emphasis on passing through checkpoints rather than racing.

199790.description:
Encantados is a filler where players assumes the role of a gardener in need to populate his garden with magical creatures. Fairies, leprechauns, gnomes, goblins and Kobolds! Every race has a special ability to help you (or disturb your friend/opposing team). Encantados knows how to balance simplicity with an awesome replay and a lot of fun. Wonderful in every way , whether in its simple mechanics, either in its neat art!

Encantados is played in a series of rounds. Every round, in alternate turns, players buy a new card and have the chance to play one Song and one Set of cards of the same Magical Creature. You can only play creatures if you have three of a kind in your hand. After you play them, they start giving you passive bonus. If one or more players empty their hand the round is over and points are counted. If, by the end of a round, a player score is 100 or higher he is the winner!

Encantados is a reimplementation with expanded number of players, new races and cards from Plato 3000.
199790.name: Encantados

199791.name: Tramid
199791.description:
"The fascinating boardgame"

Abstract race game played with tetrahedral pieces on a hexagonal board divided into six large equilateral triangle regions, each of which is subdivided into 25 equilateral triangles which are the movement spaces. The centre triangle in each of the 6 larger triangles regions is marked with a letter of the alphabet (A through F), each of which is the starting and finishing space for one of the players.

The six playing pieces are tetrahedrons, each with one face in each of the colours; red, blue, white and orange. All 6 pieces have the same colour sequence, but are distinguished by each face being marked with the letter (A to E) corresponding to the start/finishing space to which it pertains

In each game, 3 of the spaces (except the start/finish space) in each region are marked with one of the colours; red, blue or orange. The players must move from their own starting spaces, to tag all the spaces of a particular colour and return to their own starting space to finish.

The game can be played with each player required to make three laps of the boar,d once tagging ll the red spaces, then all the blue then all the orange. Alternatively players race the same coloured track as their opponent opposite in each round (e.g. players A & D race the red track, B & E the blue, and C & F the orange; then in rounds 2 & 3, swap colours).

Pieces are moved by either
a)rotating 120 degrees in place through a vertical axis (i.e. the face-down side remains face down), or
b)by pivoting the piece along one of the three edges touching the board, so that it 'rolls' into one of the 3 spaces adjacent along one of the sides of the current space.

To enter (and tag) a coloured space, the colour of the face-down side must match that of the coloured space.

Each turn a player rotates his piece in place or moves to an adjoining triangular space. First player to complete the race around the predetermined course wins.

The game does not appear to have been published in a commercial version. Rather, an 18-page manual with hand-drawn line illustrations was produced in 1986 suggesting players make their own copy of the game for tabletop play, or even construct a giant set for outdoor use.

A 3-page supplement (Modified Tramid) was produced in 1987, with proposals to improve the quality of a manufactured board, and slight changes to the rules..

199792.name: Cities of Everland
199792.description:
Cities of Everland — the first game set in the Everland world — combines elements from classic euro games with the deck-digging and card-comboing aspects of collectible card games. Players will draw from one common deck comprised of Citizens and Buildings, gather resources or more cards with workers, and attempt to create the most prestigious City over the course of four rounds.

Careful hand management is crucial, as a strict hand limit forces players to consider what to keep, while also freeing up their hand to try and find what they are searching for. Though each player is building their own unique City, common Event goals and action space rarity encourage players to constantly keep an eye on what their opponents are playing.

While being simple to learn and play, the plethora of combinations, a random setup, and dozens of unique card abilities offer players a rewarding experience for return plays.

199793.description:
Lead your tribe to glory on the island of Dokmus and become a legend!

Dokmus is a board game for 2-4 players. Your goal is to lead an expedition to the island of Dokmus, the ancestral god of your tribe. The island is represented by eight double-sided map pieces. During set-up, you randomize which side of each map piece is up and place them in a 3x3 grid so that the middle place is left empty.

The island is guarded by five Guardians, which are represented by Guardian cards. On each turn, players draft the Guardian cards so that each player gets the help of one Guardian. The Guardian cards decide turn order and they also give you special powers. With them, you can move and rotate, move your tokens, or gain first player marker for next turn.

On your turn, you have three tokens to use. You use tokens to spread your influence by placing them on the board. You can also sacrifice tokens to be able to cross waters or enter forests. Or you can just sacrifice them in a volcano. At the end of the game, you get victory points for discovered temples and ruins on the map as well as sacrificed tokens.

The layout of the islands changes constantly based on player actions, making Dokmus a dynamic, fast-paced game. So choose your Guardian, make the right sacrifices, and gain the favor of Dokmus!
199793.name: Dokmus

boardgameintegration.199847: Table Air Combat: B-17F Flying Fortress

199795.description:
Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability; The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the Bf-110C, which was used in the Battle of Britain.
199795.name: Table Air Combat: Bf-110C

boardgameintegration.199847: Table Air Combat: B-17F Flying Fortress

199796.description:
Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability; The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the Focke-Wulf Fw 190A8.
199796.name: Table Air Combat: Fw-190A8

boardgameintegration.199847: Table Air Combat: B-17F Flying Fortress

199797.description:
Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability; The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the Focke-Wulf Fw 190D.
199797.name: Table Air Combat: Fw-190D

199798.name: Harry Potter: Le jeu – 1000 questions et défis
199798.description:
From platform 9 3/4 to the final battle of Hogwards, a journey through the movies of the Harry Potter series. Answering questions, take on challenges, pay forfeits... and prove that you are the biggest fan of all times!

In this game, players roll a dice an move along the board answering questions and taking on challenges based on the 8 movies from the Harry Potter saga. Players have to act swiftly each turn is timed using an hourglass. The first to reach the last frame wins the game.

Du quai 9 3/4 à la bataille finale de Poudlard, un voyage à travers tous les films de la saga Harry Potter. Répondre aux questions, relever les défis, exécuter les gages... et prouver qu'on est le plus grand fan de tous les temps!

Dans ce jeu, les joueurs lance un dé et se déplacent le long du plateau en répondant à des questions et en réalisant des défis basés sur les 8 films de la saga Harry Potter. Les joueurs doivent agir rapidement car le temps est compté par un sablier. Le premier à atteindre la dernière case gagne la partie.

199799.description:
This game is a reimplementation of the game Machi Koro.

In this game each players takes the role of a Kiosk owners in Greece competing against each other to become to become the best in the neighborhood.

Ο Πιο Καλός Περιπτεράς is a fast-paced game for 2-5 players. Each player wants to develop their kiosk on his own terms in order to acquire all the improvement that will grant him an advantage against his opponents. On his turn, each player rolls one or two dice. If the sum of the dice rolled matches the number of a product that a player owns, he gets the effect of that product; in some cases opponents will also benefit from your die (just as you can benefit from theirs). Then, with money in hand a player can acquire improvements or additional products for his Kiosk. The first player to acquire all improvements wins!
199799.name: The Best Booth

199800.name: Hatflings!
199800.description:
Hatflings! is a fun game in which each player takes control of a halfling team in the famous "game of hats" that takes place every year in the Spring Festival of Halftown.

To win the game of hats, each team has to exchange the hat of another team for their own hat while dancing, jumping and frolicking. The game board has squares for the halfling tiles who have a hat of their color (orange or purple). Whenever a tile is placed on the 6 x 6 square board, all the adjacent tiles of the opponent team must be flipped to show the other team's hat color. The game ends when no more halflings could enter the game zone, and the winning team is the one who has more hats of their color. Different kinds of halflings, such as the big bellied ones or the halfling on stilts have special actions.

Who will win the game of hats this year?

199801.description:
"Siping (四平): China's Madrid" is a two to three players operational wargame simulates the four battles in Siping during the 2nd Chinese Civil War from 1946 to 1948.
NOTE: Siping is a city in former Mandchuria - Siping.

One player commands the CCP（中國共產黨）and the other player commands the KMT（中國國民黨）. Each turn represents one day and each hex is about 2.5 km across. There are five kinds of basic units, including infantry, artillery, cavalry, tank, and HQ. The scale of the basic unit is one regiment size. Players activate the divisional HQ to command every unit in range to barrage, move, fire, and advance after combat respectively.

Players choose the command chits they plan to use in every turn. Then one player draw one command chit to activate units in the same division. Then units can barrage adjacent enemy units, move toward different terrains, then attack adjacent enemy together. Use CRT to resolve barrage and combat result. Occupy target hex and eliminate enemy units can get victory points. Player who gets more points win the game.

To occupy city hex can increase your supply points which can use to barrage heavy artillery or get replacement units. Every scenario has asymmetrical setup forces, different victory condition, reinforcements, and tactic chits to better simulate the history.

There are five scenarios in this game: "Liberation in Siping", "Defense of Siping", "Siege of Siping", "Battle of Siping", and "Return to Siping".

Components:

1 A1 Color Map
1 A4 Player Aid (Siping map area zoom)
333 die-cut counters (5/8 inch)




NOTES: Rules in Chinese translated in English.
199801.name: Siping: China's Madrid

199802.description:
Introduced in The Real Ghostbusters cartoon, the Peoplebusters come from a universe where Ghosts are everywhere and humans are the ones who are the pesky threats. This Exclusive add-on expansion includes new variant rules, 4 Peoplebusters figures, and 4 double-sided cards with their Ghost form on one side and their character stats on the other. They can be either a Class-3 Ghost or a playable character. This CZE-Exclusive pack also includes 4 double-sided map tiles featuring Boo York and Boo York Courtrooms.

INTRODUCING A NEW WAY TO BUST! Player-versus-Player Variant is a part of the pack!

This add-on pack also includes a special rules variant for Player-versus-Player (PvP) gameplay and 8 PVP cards! In this variant, one player/team takes control of the Ghostbusters, while the other player/team controls the Peoplebusters.

When the Ghostbusters and Peoplebusters collide, it’ll be a battle for the ages, and it’s up to you and your friends to determine who wins!
199802.name: Ghostbusters: The Board Game II – Peoplebusters Pack

199803.name: Campaign Adventure: Smuggler's Run
199803.description:
From the back cover

Welcome to Smugglers Run. An adventure designed for four to five players from levels one to two. Smuggler's Run, once considered the primary pipeline for Corinthean contraband in the great City of Jor-Carmin, has been dormant for quite some time now. Officially claimed by Corinthea nearly 20 years ago when a toll was placed on the road; the farmhands and settlers along the old route have enjoyed peace and fair trade since, albeit heavily taxed. The humble villagers of Hamilton, who once would have to sneak their goods throughout the kingdom, now are simple farmers, traders, and craftsmen who are happy to play by the rules. Still, the dangers along Smuggler's Run have not entirely vanished. The players in this adventure are hired to investigate a lost caravan. What seems a simple task that any farmhand could do turns into something much more intriguing. The path to becoming a hero starts somewhere. The mysteries of Smuggler's Run may be more than just urban legends and are filled with more questions than answers, but will the players have the guile to investigate it's shady past? If they make it through to the end, it will be up to them to decide.

199804.name: Sherwyn Castle
199804.description:
From publisher blurb:

Sherwyn was the first Jarin fortification to fall to the viking raiders from Ivinia. The crew that captured it was an unruly assortment of outcasts and pirates. Despite years of inbreeding with the local Jarin, most members of Clan Sheerwyn continbue to show considerable hostility toward their Jarin subjects.

Valhakar Venril Sherwyn, is a violent and ill-tempered man; his bimonthly feasts are spectacles of drunken debauchery. Venril suspects the loyalty of Kjen and Thoen, the settlements that pay him tribute, while also carrying on a blood feud with Clan Serewyn of Marby.

The Sherwyn Castle article describes the settlement's history, government, religion, economics, and military forces. It includes a full description and color floor plans for the castle, along with color GM and player maps of the settlement. Details are given for many local craftsmen and other locations in the village. Also included is a two-page expansion of the house of Gerdeen the Witch, an ancient Jarin crone widely believed to have sorcerous powers.

Portions of this article were originally published in 1992 as part of Castles of Orbaal

199805.name: Pled Castle
199805.description:
From publisher blurb:

Pled is an Orbaalese castle located at a strategic point where the Jarig River broadens and empties into the Vaagesfjord. The Jarin folk who fished the rich waters since the 4th century BT were conquered in the last century by viking raiders from across the Sea of Ivae.

Pled's current lord is Knurri Storzand, a stubborn and brutal man despised by his Jarin subjects and unloved by many of his fellow Ivinians. Knurri has pressed a vendetta with Clan Karolaan of Vaagel as an excuse to gain eventual dominance of the entire Vaagesfjord.

The Pled Castle article describes the settlement's history, government, religion, economics, and military forces. It includes a full description and color floor plans for the castle and Clan Storzand compound, along with color GM and player maps of the settlement. Details are given for many local craftsmen and other locations in the village.

Portions of this article were originally published in 1992 as part of Castles of Orbaal

199806.name: Falling of the Rain
199806.description:
From the Front of the Book:

Rain has been falling heavily for several days, tempers are on edge, gutters are overflowing and a tangled web is forming among different factions in the city sewers.

It's an opportunity for new adventurers to get started and make their mark!

A 2-hour adventure for first level characters.

199807.name: A Quiet Life
199807.description:
From publisher blurb:

As the heroes travel through the Outlands, they come upon a small village, which seems to be in the midst of serious construction. They soon learn that a band of Accursed recently visited the town, and demanded that the refugees who settle it leave. As it turns out, those Accursed dwelt here, long before the Bane War began. Needless to say, they're unhappy about the refugees stealing their homes and land. The Witchmarked heroes must decide which party is in the right, and try to resolve their conflict, lest blood be shed between those who still oppose the Witches.

A Quiet Life is a 1-Sheet style scenario that focuses on the adventures of a band of Witchmarked heroes in the Accursed game setting. The adventure may be played as a standalone, or it may be used with the Plot Point Campaign included in Accursed. The adventure features brief scene descriptionss, with necessary game mechanics and opportunity for tasks that can be resolved in a variety of ways.

199808.name: Beneath the Storm
199808.description:
From the Front of the Book:

As the rain continues to fall, the sewers have become a haven for undesirables but moving them on will be difficult as certain parties seek out a dark and ancient secret.

A 3-hour adventure for 3rd level characters in the 5th edition of an awesome roleplaying game.

199809.name: Khimera: Destroy All Monster Girls
199809.description:
Part human, part oni, golem and harpy! The list goes on and on! Born in a lab, Chelshia the chimera is the world's first synthetic monster girl. When her monster inhabited island home is threatened by a band of looting pirates, she springs into action to save the day!

Khimera: Destroy All Monster Girls is your premiere monster girl beat-em-up platformer experience! Use Suits & Sandals' patented (not actually patented) GIANT STONE FIST technology to punch your way through hordes of monster-pirates to reclaim your home's stolen treasure.

Find upgrades, collect collectables and solve problems with your fists! Play the game at your own pace in story mode or go for the best time in a marathon-style race mode!

Source: The Developer Website.

199810.name: Black of the Rainbow
199810.description:
From the Front of the Book:

There is trouble afoot as an old friend calls for help. The cult of the Black Rainbow are ready to make their move. An ancient legend is coming to life and the sewers of Vollenchia will never be the same.

A 5-hour adventure for 6th level characters.

199811.name: Old Frog and Toad
199811.description:
From the Front of the Book:

Trade caravans are being attacked on the main road. Usually this just means more guards are needed, and that is a call any young band of adventurers will respond to. Keep an eye out as there is more than one band of trouble-makers out there.

A 2-hour adventure for 2nd level characters for the 5th edition of the world’s most popular role playing game

199812.name: Sylvan Blood
199812.description:
From the Front of the Book:

Within an ancient sanctuary grove where fey and druids once lived in peace. Blood now soaks the ground... It started with love, turned to hate and now is driven by madness.

A 3-hour story of love and pain for 7th level characters using the 5th edition of the most played role playing game in the world.

199813.name: The Sound of Drums
199813.description:
From the Front of the Book:

There are rumblings in the background. A slow build of events spaced out as random happenings and a minor story that evolves over time into the coming of war.

A series of mini-adventures for 1st to 7th level characters for the 5th edition of our favorite role playing game.

199814.name: Equipment Tricks for Bows
199814.description:
From publisher blurb:

With a wealth of feat options at a player’s disposal, it can be difficult to find something new to define your character. The Equipment Trick feat introduced new ways to specialize around the gear you use the most, differentiating your character from every other rank-and-file adventurer. With Sidebar: Equipment Tricks for Bows, you’ll find a dozen exciting new ways to employ this legendary ranged weapon, both in and out of combat. Robin Hood managed—so why would you ever need another weapon?

199815.name: The Golden Kingdoms Campaign Setting: A Sourcebook for Lazy World Builders
199815.description:
From the Introduction:

Building a world is hard work. You need a map, you need countries, you need cities, you need histories. The list of things you need is long. Even worse, you need players who will read it all! You can purchase a world, but that is expensive and then there is a lot of reading. Again, its hard work.

This whole concept is to take that work away. Get a map that is already drawn. Cover it with countries and cultures that already exist. Just tweak it a bit and everything is right there ready to play.

It’s not just for lazy DMs, it is for any DM who wants to prioritise their time and focus on story rather than background.

199816.name: Heroes of the Dawn
199816.description:
From the Front of the Book:

Rats in the Rain Presents:
Blade Shaper
Wilderness Runner
War Chanter
Rat Catcher

A handbook of class options for the 5th edition of the world’s greatest role playing game.

199817.name: Masters of Fate
199817.description:
'From the Front of the Book:

Rats in the Rain Presents:

Magehand Pilferer
Jack of the Trades
War Druid
Night Watchman

A handbook of class options for the 5th edition of the world’s greatest role playing game.

199818.name: Warriors of destiny
199818.description:
'From the Front of the Book:

Rats in the Rain Presents:

Druidic Lyrist
Ninja
Eldritch Archer
Tavern Owner

A handbook of class options for the 5th edition of the world’s greatest role playing game.

199819.name: Seekers of Fortune
199819.description:
'From the Front of the Book:

Rats in the Rain Presents:

Master Thrower
Harlequin
Mountain Defender
Town Crier

A handbook of class options for the 5th edition of the world’s greatest role playing game

199821.name: Criminal Intent
199821.description:
From publisher blurb:

Backgrounds for Criminals and the Lawless!

In the world of 5th Edition fantasy, a character’s choice of background represents where he or she came from, and better defines a character’s place and role in the world of the game. Selecting a background provides a player with important hints and clues as to how best to portray their character in action, as well as outfitting the GM with hooks to hang important plot developments on.

Furthermore, a player’s choice of background may equip his or her character with useful skills, proficiencies, and other features as well as providing a basis for his or her personality traits, ideals, bonds, and flaws – all important pieces of the inspiration system. Contained herein are four backgrounds for members of the criminal element: the Convict, the Fence, the Grave Robber, and the Thieves’ Guild Thug.

199822.name: Web Shelter
199822.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Spell Power PDFs introduce two pages of themed content for use with the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game. Every PDF contains a full page of high-quality content (no fluff or filler)!

Spell Power: Web Shelter includes a handful of new feats for fans of the web shelter spell, plus plot hooks to bring your adventurers in quickly using this spell and these feats!

199823.name: Quantum Collapse Issue #0: One Hero, Many Possibilities
199823.description:
From publisher blurb:

In a universe with infinite possibilities, there are some interesting phenomena. What if a super-hero existed within several different realities? How would he advance in power if the energy from his parallel identities was spread amongst the survivors? How would he be different in a world where the American Revolution never happened? What about if the Allies lost World War II?

Meet Hurricane, a former football player turned meteorologist who recently was imbued with super powers. He is presented at power levels 6, 8, 10, 12, and 16. Additionally, see how his world would be different with four alternate world histories. Hurricane is ready to be a friend or a foe in your Mutants and Masterminds game, featuring the Quantum Collapse campaign setting.

199824.name: A Fistful of Horror: 03
199824.description:
From publisher blurb:

From the author of the '100' series of Adventure Seeds books, a new, shorter form source of inspiration for Games Masters. They might be adventures, non-player-characters, monsters, places... all ready to be dropped into your campaign, regardless of system.

This booklet presents five horror scenarios with inspirational art by Brad McDevitt.

199825.description:
In this first episode of the Danger! Danger! series, the players find themselves transported to a wild prehistoric fantasy land; where, as Cavefolk, they must explore the dinosaur infested jungle in order to secure their basic needs: food, water, and fire! Along the way, players may secure victory points by earning Big Idea cards, Tool Bonus cards, Bone Artifact cards,and Cavefolk Retirement cards.

At its core, the Danger! Danger! dice system is a four phase, press your luck dice engine that will have the players testing the limits of their good fortune! Here are the 4 phases:

1. The player rolls the exploration dice. They may keep the roll and spend their dice to earn cards and/or token (thus ending their turn)...OR...
2. The player may reroll any unwanted dice +1 Dinosaur dice
3. The player may reroll any unwanted dice +2 Dinosaur dice
4. The player may reroll any unwanted dice +3 Dinosaur dice

Each phase the player has two choices: spend the dice (and end their turn), or reroll any unwanted dice, however, each time a Dinosaur dice is added, the chance of busting grows ever greater!

The players take turns pressing their luck, round after round, until one of two primary decks are depleted. The player with the most victory points at the end of the game stands victorious!
199825.name: Danger! Danger! Dinosaur

199826.name: Horrors of the Aboleth
199826.description:
From publisher blurb:

“Just when you thought it was safe to adventure in the water!”

Aboleth are an empire of entirely inhuman intelligences who are older, smarter, and more vile than most land-based races. This book assumes that a race as old and powerful as aboleth, and as prone to manipulating and transmogrifying other races, is going to have a great deal more in their empire than just their core race and skum servants.

We present a wide range of noisome and disquieting new threats, ready to turn their alien intellects to the destruction of the PCs’ world. So prepare to behold the behemoth, face the slime golems, and flee the tentacle crabs. Nothing can save you now.

199828.name: Triomphe
199828.description:
Triomphe (French for triumph) is a card game dating from the late 15th century. It most likely originated in France or Spain (as triunfo) and later spread to the rest of Europe.

This game is the origin of the English word "trump" and is the ancestor of many trick-taking games like Euchre (via Écarté) and Whist (via Ruff and Honours).

199829.name: Star Fox Zero + Star Fox Guard

videogamehonor.41850: 2016 Golden Geek Best Wii U Game Runner Up

199829.description:
User Summary

Star Fox Zero is a third person sci-fi action game and the sixth installment in the Star Fox series.

Came with Guard bundled.

199830.name: 骸骨王VSボドゲ探偵 (Skeleton King vs Boardgame Detective)
199830.description:
User summary
骸骨王VSボドゲ探偵 (Gaikotuou tai Bodogetantei) means Skeleton King vs Boardgame Detective in English. This is a 12 card expansion deck for the game Criminal 're In Detective. In this extension of the rules, it is possible that the culprit can kill the detective.

Publisher's summary
Criminal 're In Detective の拡張カードセットです。この拡張ルールでは、犯人が探偵を殺すことが可能です。

199831.name: FAITH: A Garden in Hell – Starter set
199831.description:
A Garden in Hell gives you a complete pick-up-and-play campaign containing everything you need to roleplay in the Faith Universe right out of the box.

Background: The fragile truce between the Iz'kal and the Corvo had been compromised by a series of murderous attacks on far away settlements. Mutually Assured Destruction was days away as both species laid blame on each other... when the Battle of Izuan Tai shook the groundwork of the known Universe. It was the first big blow the legendary species of the Ravager would deliver to civilisation, but it wouldn't be the last. A new menace had awoken from a long sleep.

A Garden in Hell takes place 23 years after the Battle of Izuan Tai, where the rival Iz’Kal and Corvo species joined forces to stop the mutual threat and formed The Coalition. This entity has now become a “third state” independent of both the Iz’Kal and the Corvo, with emergency powers over all areas threatened by the Ravager.

On its last military council, the Coalition high command agreed it was time to leave their defensive stand and strike back in full force to capture a Ravager Queen. At first, the attack was a thundering success, but when the injured Ravager Queen entered the Labyrinth only your group was able to chase her unscathed deep into Ravager territory…

In A Garden in Hell you might...

...survive in the alien planet Ujara, fighting off its dangerous flora and fauna.

...set up camp with allies who will help in your endeavours.

...run combat, diplomacy and reconnaissance missions.

...meet the Kira, the native species, whose lives are shaken by your arrival.

...discover the origins of the mutant Ravager, their motivations, and their goals.

...take advantage of their power struggles, as a Herald of Extinction revolts against her Queen.

...participate in an epic final showdown against the ultimate enemy.

...behold the awe-inspiring landscapes and alluring vistas of this GARDEN IN HELL.

199832.name: Annwyvvn: A Celtic Heresy
199832.description:
From the introduction:

The setting for this campaign is mostly northern European, especially the Celtic, Anglo-Saxon, and Norse lands. There is also a possibility of reaching the magical Elven lands of Annwyvvn (Welsh), Tir Na Og (Irish), or even Alfheim/Elfeheim (Nordic/Germanic). The campaign theme is the promotion of the Celtic heresy and the discovery of the Elven lands, which have been lost since the paths to those lands were suppressed by the Roman Catholic Church. There is also a problematic, and somewhat unspecified rise of evil forces, led by one only known as 'The Bright Star'. Theologians can work out form themselves the relationship between this is with the comments in Revelations or the Finno-Ugarian god Jumala, and their association with the Pole Star.

199833.description:
Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability; The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the TBF-1C Avenger. Also known as the TBM, Avengers were effective torpedo bombers in the Pacific.
199833.name: Table Air Combat: TBF-1 Avenger

199836.name: Everyman Options: Kineticists
199836.description:
From publisher blurb:

New from Everyman Gaming, LLC!

Wield the elements like never before with Everyman Options: Kineticist! Within, you will find:

Psychokineticists; kineticists who manipulate the raw psychic energy of the Dimension of Dreams in order to command an all-new dream element.
Six all-new archetypes, ranging from the destructive elemental blade and elemental marksman to the possesses harbinger and the shapeshifting metabolic elementalist.
Advanced Composite Blasts, which allow hydrokineticists and pyrokineticists to combine their elements with planar power.
The Scion of the Elements prestige class, which allows a kineticist to master all four elements and bring balance to the world.

199837.name: Gold Lion
199837.description:
From publisher blurb:

The King Defends His People

Ade Mujambe Lisimba, King of Ophar, is his people's protector, and the country's greatest treasure, the Gold Lion (PL 10).

His birthright stolen by interlopers, Ade fought to get it back, don the orichalchum armor and weapons, and defeat the Silverback who killed his father.

A powerful voice in world politics, Ade has slowly opened the borders of his kingdom in order to help improve the collective world of technology. He fights against greed, racial and social injustice, and selfish environmental practices. Between him, and his rumored romantic parther, Princess Euadne of Atlantis, there are few more powerful in the mystic world.

199838.name: Empires Of The Undergrowth
199838.description:
UNRELEASED GAME – UNAVAILABLE




This game has officially been announced by the publisher or developer, but has not yet been released and made available for purchase. Therefore some of the information above may change in the future. Until this game is released, please do not submit images for it, nor add new releases. Press Kits are an exception and a maximum of six can be added.




Game Features:


Carve out and construct your underground nest to suit your strategy.
Engage in fast-paced colony versus colony combat above ground.
Absorb new species into your colony, then enhance them with upgrades and combat boosts.
Encounter and overpower awesome Titans of the Undergrowth.
Epic campaign story told from the perspective of a documentary team and inspired by real world challenges


Source: The Game Website.

199839.name: Earthdawn Gamemaster's Guide (4th Edition)
199839.description:
From the back of the book:

The Age of Legend
An age of magic once existed in our world. Lost to history, this time is remembered in the echoes of myth and legend. Humans lived alongside the other Namegiver races—dwarf and elf, troll and ork, windling, t’skrang and obsidiman. The wild places of the world were home to griffins, shadowmants, and other fantastic beasts.
The land was once besieged by the Horrors, foul creatures from the depths of astral space that sought to feed upon and destroy all that was living and good. Their time—the time of the Scourge—has passed, and the people have returned to the surface, reclaiming the lands that were once their home.
Brave heroes band together to explore the land of Barsaive, fighting the Horrors that remain, and protecting their homes and families from those that would enslave them.
The Gamemaster’s Guide provides rules and advice for running the Earthdawn game, and includes an exploration of the lands of Barsaive, as well as numerous fantastic creatures and magical treasures to challenge and reward your players!

199840.name: Earthdawn Gamemaster's Screen (4th Edition)
199840.description:
From the back:

Smooth out the sometimes treacherous path of gamemastering! Included in this packet is a four-panel cardstock screen that displays commonly used charts and tables for easy reference, and also provides a place to conceal adventure notes and dice rolls. For tables not included on the screen, a full index of charts and tables in both the Player's Guide and Gamemaster's Guide is provided, making it easy to find what you're looking for.

Also included in the 32-page booklet are sixty pre-generated adepts! Based on the sample characters from the Earthdawn Player's Guide, you get four examples of each core Discipline, advanced to Circles 2, 4, 6, and 8. Talent selections, derived characteristics, and sample magic items are provided for each, making these characters a great way to provide short-notice allies or enemies for your game!

In addition to the sample characters, the PDF version of this product provides a high-resolution image from the front of the screen, with the GM-side divided into four pages that you can print and use as you wish, constructing your own screen.

199841.name: Sword & Backpack: The Young Adventurer's Almanac
199841.description:
User summary:

The game is intended for use as an introductory game for new, inexperienced players. The game is suitable for use with an entire group of new players and even a relatively inexperienced game master. Characters are defined through narrative play. Action resolution uses a possibly modified d20 roll against a target difficulty.

199842.name: Sword & Backpack Adventure Setting: Lanternport
199842.description:
User summary:

Ah, Lanternport -- the City of Torches! Besides being home to the offices of Rothbard & Gazpus, the publishers of Sword & Backpack (24 Maguslane, near the Librarium Infinitum), Lanternport is one of the primary commercial and cultural hubs of the Known Kingdoms. Home to over 200,000 souls of different races, it is a melting pot of wonder, adventure and danger, a grand metropolis that can be all things to all people. Surrounded by a protective wall and bordered by cliffs, forests, hills and placid Lantern Bay, Lanternport has natural protection against invasion by land and sea (see the map on the next page), and attracts visitors and immigrants from all points of the compass rose.

199843.name: Sword & Backpack Adventure Supplement 1
199843.description:
User summary:

These short adventure seeds are meant to spark the imagination of Storytellers. They’re rough outlines, bones sans flesh, stage directions in search of a play, with the details left to the whims of whoever’s running the adventure.

199844.name: Sword & Backpack Adventure Supplement 2
199844.description:
User summary:

Includes two concise adventure hooks, with plot, characters, monsters, twists, rewards, and art - all on one tiny page.

Includes these adventures:


All Along the Watchtower of Death
The Lichburg Hustle

199845.name: Sword & Backpack Magic Supplement
199845.description:
User summary:

In Sword & Backpack, casting spells is not simply a matter of saying "I want to cast this spell." Players must be able to memorize and recite their spells aloud. Tricky, eh?

In this first Magic Supplement, you will find 15 beginning spells. As a neophyte sorcerer, you are asked to carefully select three and only three of these spells and affix them into your book. This is the beginning of your spellbook, and it is the sorcerer’s job to commit the short spell verses to memory.

199846.name: Sword & Backpack Collected Broadsheets
199846.description:
From the introduction:

It is the opinion of the authors of this book that any adventurer worthy of the title must possess, at the bare minimum, two essential items to prosecute their trade successfully. They must have a sword and a backpack.

User summary:

Includes various game rules, suggestions, and ideas - all presented as if they were published in-game.

199847.description:
Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability. The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the B-17F, the four-engined bomber that was the backbone of the industrial war against Germany.
199847.name: Table Air Combat: B-17F Flying Fortress

199848.description:
Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability. The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the F4F-4 Wildcat. Wildcats were used in the early Pacific war, where they fought against the superior Zero.
199848.name: Table Air Combat: F4F-4 Wildcat

199849.name: Peekaboom
199849.description:
PEEKABOOM is a fast and outrageously fun strategy game where you work with your partner to assemble and detonate your explosive device before your opponents can detonate theirs.

Sounds easy? Not so fast! You need to use secret signals to let your partner know when your device is ready to explode. Don’t make it too obvious or you’ll get caught. But if it’s not obvious enough, your partner won’t notice it… And don’t forget to watch your opponents or you’ll miss their secret signals!

Game Play:
At the start of the game, each player gets a secret signal card, 3 explosives cards (the player's hand) and a stack of unknown explosives cards. To start a round, each player takes a card from the top of their stack and places it face up in the center of the table. Then the player tries to collect 3 of a kind by discarding a card from their hand and collecting one from the center of the table. There are no turns - players collect cards simultaneously. As soon as a player has 3 of a kind, he or she performs the secret signal described on the secret signal card (e.g. touch your nose, tap the table, etc...). If the player's partner sees the signal and shouts 'BOOM!' that team wins the round. If an opponent sees the signal and shouts 'SNIP!' the opponent's team wins the round. The first team to reach 10 points wins (7 points for a 6 player game).

Advanced strategies:

Bluff! Send fake signals to make your opponents mistakenly say ‘SNIP!’.
Watch what explosives your opponents are collecting. Enjoy the look of surprise on their faces when you say ‘SNIP!’ before they have even made their signal.
Alternatively, if you see an opponent collecting a particular explosive, grab it when it appears on the table before they manage to grab it themselves.
Even better, if you already have an opponent’s card in your hand, play it and say ‘SNIP!’ as soon as he or she picks it up.
You should also watch what your partner is collecting, maybe you have a card he or she can use.
Watch for players who aren’t collecting any cards, they probably have collected 3 of a kind already.
Confuse your opponent by constantly dropping and collecting extra cards so that they can’t see what explosives you are really collecting.
There are blank signal cards in the Signals deck. Make up your own signals.
For more advanced players - don’t use the Signals deck at all! Each team makes up 3 Signals before the game and uses them from start to finish.

boardgameintegration.199847: Table Air Combat: B-17F Flying Fortress

199850.description:
Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
